{{For|the airport near Sanford, North Carolina|Sanford-Lee County Regional Airport}} {{Infobox airport | name = Sanford Seacoast Regional Airport | image = | image-width = | caption = | IATA = SFM | ICAO = KSFM | FAA = SFM | type = Public | owner = Town of Sanford | operator = | city-served = | location = [[Sanford, Maine]] | elevation-f = 244 | elevation-m = 74 | coordinates = {{Coord|43|23|38|N|070|42|29|W|type:airport_region:US}} | website = | r1-number = 7/25 | r1-length-f = 6,389 | r1-length-m = 1,947 | r1-surface = [[Asphalt]] | r2-number = 14/32 | r2-length-f = 4,999 | r2-length-m = 1,524 | r2-surface = Asphalt | stat-year = 2006 | stat1-header = Aircraft operations | stat1-data = 76,010 | stat2-header = Based aircraft | stat2-data = 78 | footnotes = Source: [[Federal Aviation Administration]]<ref name=FAA>{{FAA-airport|ID=SFM|use=PU|own=PU|site=08275.*A}}, retrieved 15 March 2007</ref> }}
'''Sanford Seacoast Regional Airport''' {{Airport codes|SFM|KSFM|SFM}} is a public [[airport]] located four miles (6 km) southeast of the [[central business district]] of [[Sanford, Maine|Sanford]], a town in [[York County, Maine|York County]], [[Maine]], [[United States]]. The airport operated as Sanford Naval Auxiliary Air Facility (NAAF) supporting operations of [[Naval Air Station Brunswick]] from 15 April 1943 until 1 February 1946.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.history.navy.mil/avh-vol2/Appen6.pdf|title=Patrol Squadron Shore Establishments|publisher=United States Navy|accessdate=2012-03-07}}</ref> This airport is now publicly owned by Town of Sanford.<ref name=FAA />
==Facilities and aircraft== Sanford Regional Airport covers an area of {{convert|1,115|acre|ha|lk=on}} which contains two [[runway]]s:<ref name=FAA /> * Runway 7/25: 6,389 x 150 ft (1,947 x 46 m), Surface: Asphalt * Runway 14/32: 4,999 x 100 ft (1,524 x 30 m), Surface: Asphalt
For 12-month period ending 29 August 2006 the airport had 76,010 aircraft operations, an average of 208 per day: 96% general aviation (72,640), 4% air taxi (3,350) and <1% military (20). There are 78 aircraft based at this airport: 92% single engine (72) and 8% multi engine (6).<ref name=FAA />
==Fixed-Base Operator and Flight Schools== There is a fixed-base operator (FBO) and several flight schools on the airfield.
The FBO is Southern Maine Aviation, which has Jet Fuel, Aviation Gasoline (100LL) and MoGas (usually available). They also operate an aircraft maintenance facility, a flight school and have facilities for transient flight crew and passengers.<ref name="flyingsma.com">http://flyingsma.com</ref>
There are three flight schools on the field: * Southern Maine Aviation provides instruction in single engine airplanes, including a Gobosh, an American Champion Citabria, a Cessna 172M, a pair of Cessna 172-SPs, a complex Cessna 182 and a RedBird Simulator.<ref name="flyingsma.com"/> * York County Helicopters provides instruction in Robinson R22s and R44s.<ref>http://yorkcountyhelicopters.net/Pages/Files/Rates.html</ref> * Sanford Soaring provides instruction in gliders to club members.<ref>http://sanfordsoaring.com</ref>
==History== {{Infobox NRHP | name = Sanford Naval Air Station Administration Building--Control Tower, Former | nrhp_type = | image = SanfordAirStationTower.png | caption = The NAAS tower, c. 1995 | built = {{Start date|1942}} | architect OR builder = UNITED STATES NAVY | architecture = WWII NAVAL CONTROL TOWERS | added = June 20, 1997 | area = less than one acre | governing_body = Private | refnum = 97000603<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref> }} The Sanford Airport began as an airfield constructed by the Sanford Mills in the 1930s, with a single airstrip and hangar. With the entry of the United States into [[World War II]] in 1941, the airfield was expanded by the [[United States Navy]] in 1942 and formally commissioned as the Sanford Naval Auxiliary Air Facility in 1943. It served as one of several secondary airfields to the primary [[Brunswick Naval Air Station]]. Its runway network was enlarged and paved, and barracks and a control tower were built on what is now the southwestern side of the airfield. A torpedo squadron and a fighter squadron were stationed here in 1944, and the field was used for training exercises. After the war ended, the facilities were largely mothballed, but remained manned until the 1960s. Of the structures built by the Navy, only a hangar and the control tower/administration building survived.<ref name=NRHP>{{cite web|url={{NRHP url|id=97000603}}|title=NRHP nomination for Sanford Naval Air Station Administration Building-Control Tower, Former|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2015-09-12}}</ref> The latter, listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1997,<ref name="nris"/> was demolished in 2006-07 because it was in poor condition and the tower was deemed a hazard to aviation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digitalcommons.library.umaine.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1973&context=towndocs|title=2006-7 Sanford Town Report|publisher=Town of Sanford|accessdate=2014-10-02}}</ref>
